  physical_appearance: The image consists of a large brocde stole and a smaller one. Both are rectangular in shape and predominantly green and white in colour. It has diaper patterns that extend all over its surface. The sides of each lozenge is a fish
 and in the centre there is a tortoise with red eyes. The big brocade stole has two holes
 one at its lower right side and the other towards its left side at its horizontal mid-point.

  subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) motifs Hinduism symbolism (artistic concept) diaper patterns allover patterns avatara

  subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Motifs Avatars (Religion) Hinduism Shawls Hindu symbolism Vishnu (Hindu deity)

  subject_terms_3: Hinduism

  sgcool_label_text: This is a brocade from the Gujarat region of western India. Gujarat was a major centre of textile manufacture and trade
 and Gujarati brocades were of fine design and craftsmanship. Although weaving has a long history in the region
 many techniques and motifs were brought in from Persia during the reign of the Mughals. Traditional Indian patterns
 such as flora and fauna were also integrated into the new approach
 leading to the depictions of various symbols on textile.\r\n\r\nThis brocade symbolically represents Vishnu – the trellis pattern is formed by a very unusual fish pattern
 while the central motif is a tortoise. The fish and tortoise are the first and second avatars of Vishnu.

metadata.physical_appearance: The image consists of a large brocde stole and a smaller one. Both are rectangular in shape and predominantly green and white in colour. It has diaper patterns that extend all over its surface. The sides of each lozenge is a fish, and in the centre there is a tortoise with red eyes. The big brocade stole has two holes, one at its lower right side and the other towards its left side at its horizontal mid-point.
metadata.subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) motifs Hinduism symbolism (artistic concept) diaper patterns allover patterns avatara
metadata.subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Motifs Avatars (Religion) Hinduism Shawls Hindu symbolism Vishnu (Hindu deity)
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This is a brocade from the Gujarat region of western India. Gujarat was a major centre of textile manufacture and trade, and Gujarati brocades were of fine design and craftsmanship. Although weaving has a long history in the region, many techniques and motifs were brought in from Persia during the reign of the Mughals. Traditional Indian patterns, such as flora and fauna were also integrated into the new approach, leading to the depictions of various symbols on textile.

This brocade symbolically represents Vishnu – the trellis pattern is formed by a very unusual fish pattern, while the central motif is a tortoise. The fish and tortoise are the first and second avatars of Vishnu.
